natural problem: Circle $C$ has radius 10 cm. How many square centimeters are in the area of the largest possible inscribed triangle having one side as a diameter of circle $C$?
natural solution: We may consider the diameter of circle $C$ as the base of the inscribed triangle; its length is $20\text{ cm}$. Then the corresponding height extends from some point on the diameter to some point on the circle $C$.

The greatest possible height is a radius of $C$, achieved when the triangle is right isosceles: [asy] unitsize(8); draw(Circle((0,0),10)); draw(((-10,0)--(10,0))); label("$20$",(0,0),S); draw(((-10,-0.8)--(-0.8,-0.6)),BeginArrow);

draw(((0.8,-0.8)--(10,-0.8)),EndArrow); draw(((-10,0)--(0,10))); draw(((0,10)--(10,0))); draw(((0,0)--(0,10)),dashed); label("$10$",(0,2.5),E); [/asy] In this case, the height is $10\text{ cm}$, so the area of the triangle is $$\frac 12\cdot 20\cdot 10 = \boxed{100}\text{ square centimeters}.$$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes C r a :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "a = r powr 2 / 2"
shows  "a = 100"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $C$ has radius 10 cm. How many square centimeters are in the area of the largest possible inscribed triangle having one side as a diameter of circle $C$? The final Answer is 100
 ### Proof
 We may consider the diameter of circle $C$ as the base of the inscribed triangle; its length is $20\text{ cm}$. Then the corresponding height extends from some point on the diameter to some point on the circle $C$.
 The greatest possible height is a radius of $C$, achieved when the triangle is right isosceles: [asy] unitsize(8); draw(Circle((0,0),10)); draw(((-10,0)--(10,0))); label("$20$",(0,0),S); draw(((-10,-0.8)--(-0.8,-0.6)),BeginArrow);
 draw(((0.8,-0.8)--(10,-0.8)),EndArrow); draw(((-10,0)--(0,10))); draw(((0,10)--(10,0))); draw(((0,0)--(0,10)),dashed); label("$10$",(0,2.5),E); [/asy] In this case, the height is $10\text{ cm}$, so the area of the triangle is $$\frac 12\cdot 20\cdot 10 = \boxed{100}\text{ square centimeters}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes C r a :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "a = r powr 2 / 2"
shows  "a = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the value of $a$ if $a = r^2 / 2$ and $r = 10$. The final answer is $100$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r :: real and A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> r. A r = 0.5 * r * r"
shows  "A r = 100"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $C$ has radius 10 cm. How many square centimeters are in the area of the largest possible inscribed triangle having one side as a diameter of circle $C$? The final Answer is 100
 ### Proof
 We may consider the diameter of circle $C$ as the base of the inscribed triangle; its length is $20\text{ cm}$. Then the corresponding height extends from some point on the diameter to some point on the circle $C$.
 The greatest possible height is a radius of $C$, achieved when the triangle is right isosceles: [asy] unitsize(8); draw(Circle((0,0),10)); draw(((-10,0)--(10,0))); label("$20$",(0,0),S); draw(((-10,-0.8)--(-0.8,-0.6)),BeginArrow);

 *)

theorem
fixes r :: real and A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> r. A r = 0.5 * r * r"
shows  "A r = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the area of a circle with radius $r = 10$. Use the formula for the area of a circle $A(r) = 0.5 * r^2$. The final answer is $100$.

a_2.formal problem:

fixes r :: real and area_triangle :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> r. area_triangle r = r powr 2"
shows  "area_triangle r = 100"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r :: real and C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. C x = pi * r powr 2"
and h1 : "r = 10"
shows  "C (diameter / 2) = 100"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
shows  "let s = 2 * r; a = s * (sqrt ((s/2) powr 2 - (r powr 2))) / 2 in a = 100"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $C$ has radius 10 cm. How many square centimeters are in the area of the largest possible inscribed triangle having one side as a diameter of circle $C$? The final Answer is 100
 ### Proof
 We may consider the diameter of circle $C$ as the base of the inscribed triangle; its length is $20\text{ cm}$. Then the corresponding height extends from some point on the diameter to some point on the circle $C$.
 The greatest possible height is a radius of $C$, achieved when the triangle is right isosceles: [asy] unitsize(8); draw(Circle((0,0),10)); draw(((-10,0)--(10,0))); label("$20$",(0,0),S); draw(((-10,-0.8)--(-0.8,-0.6)),BeginArrow);

 *)

theorem
fixes r :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
shows  "let s = 2 * r; a = s * (sqrt ((s/2) powr 2 - (r powr 2))) / 2 in a = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given that the radius of a circle is 10, find the area of the largest possible isosceles triangle that can be inscribed in the circle. The final answer is 100.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> A. is_triangle A \<and> inscribed_circle A C r \<longrightarrow> area A \<le> r powr 2"
shows  "\<exists> A. is_triangle A \<and> inscribed_circle A C r \<and> area A = 100"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $C$ has radius 10 cm. How many square centimeters are in the area of the largest possible inscribed triangle having one side as a diameter of circle $C$? The final Answer is 100
 ### Proof
 We may consider the diameter of circle $C$ as the base of the inscribed triangle; its length is $20\text{ cm}$. Then the corresponding height extends from some point on the diameter to some point on the circle $C$.
 The greatest possible height is a radius of $C$, achieved when the triangle is right isosceles: [asy] unitsize(8); draw(Circle((0,0),10)); draw(((-10,0)--(10,0))); label("$20$",(0,0),S); draw(((-10,-0.8)--(-0.8,-0.6)),BeginArrow);

 *)

theorem
fixes r :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> A. is_triangle A \<and> inscribed_circle A C r \<longrightarrow> area A \<le> r powr 2"
shows  "\<exists> A. is_triangle A \<and> inscribed_circle A C r \<and> area A = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a circle of radius 10, is it possible to inscribe a triangle within the circle such that the area of the triangle is 100?

fixes r :: real and A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> r. A r = pi * r powr 2 / 2"
shows  "A r = 100"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r :: real and A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> r. A r = 0.5 * r * r"
and h2 : "A r \<le> pi * r * r"
shows  "A r = 100"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Circle $C$ has radius 10 cm. How many square centimeters are in the area of the largest possible inscribed triangle having one side as a diameter of circle $C$? The final Answer is 100
 ### Proof
 We may consider the diameter of circle $C$ as the base of the inscribed triangle; its length is $20\text{ cm}$. Then the corresponding height extends from some point on the diameter to some point on the circle $C$.
 The greatest possible height is a radius of $C$, achieved when the triangle is right isosceles: [asy] unitsize(8); draw(Circle((0,0),10)); draw(((-10,0)--(10,0))); label("$20$",(0,0),S); draw(((-10,-0.8)--(-0.8,-0.6)),BeginArrow);

 *)

theorem
fixes r :: real and A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> r. A r = 0.5 * r * r"
and h2 : "A r \<le> pi * r * r"
shows  "A r = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a circle with radius 10, find the area of a sector of that circle which is less than or equal to the total area of the circle, if the area of the sector is given by the formula $A(r) = 0.5r^2$. The final answer is $100$.
